Configuration.StudyNameEntrez: National Institute on Aging (NIA) SardiNIA Study
Configuration.StudyNameReportPage: National Institute on Aging (NIA) SardiNIA Study
Configuration.Description:
Sardinia is the second largest island in the Mediterranean and constitutes a genetically isolated founder population. This population has aided in the identification of genes involved in several Mendelian disorders and is attractive for genetic studies due to its organization in long-established settlements that developed from an initial group of founder settlers (~1,000) thousands of years ago. The current study has recruited 6,148 Sardinians aged 14 and older, from a cluster of four towns in the Lanusei Valley in the Ogliastra region of the province of Nuoro. This sample corresponds to approximately 62% of the population eligible in the area for recruitment. Information collected during enrollment allowed the individuals to be organized into 711 complex pedigrees, each up to five generations deep, with an average kinship coefficient of 0.1628. All volunteers have been characterized for 98 quantitative traits. Traits include anthropomorphic measures, plasma and serum markers (including cholesterol and other markers of cardiovascular disease), and personality traits (using the five-factor model).

The main goal of the study is to examine phenotypic similarities between relatives that yield information on the overall contributions of genes to trait variability. Data given here provide p-values for 98 traits studied in 1,412 individuals, based on genotyping with the Affymetrix 500K chip and imputed markers using the HapMap population as a reference (N=2,259,179). Sharing this genome assessment data at high level of resolution for a variety of quantitative traits will be useful for other groups to validate newly observed associations and to investigate possible pleiotropic effects.

For ulterior information, and in particular for any individual genotype information, a formal request should be addressed to the Steering Committee, c/o David Schlessinger, Chief, Laboratory of Genetics, National Institute on Aging, National Institutes of Health, NIH Biomedical Research Center, 251 Bayview Blvd., Suite 100 Baltimore, MD 21224 USA and should include IRB approval of a detailed proposal, along with a signed statement guaranteeing that no attempt will be made to identify any individual participant.
Configuration.StudyInEx: Participant ages were 14 years and older. Among the 1,412 individuals included in this project, there were 659 males and 753 females. All analyses were conducted using age, age squared and sex as covariates, and traits were transformed using quantile normalization.

Configuration.StudyHistory:
2001: Project started
2006: First publication in PLoS Genetics on heritability estimation of 98 quantitative traits
2007: First genome-wide association scan publication in PLoS Genetics

DacInfo.DacFullName: Joint Addiction, Aging, and Mental Health DAC

Analysis.Description: We recruited a cohort of 6,148 participants, aged 14-102 y, from four clustered towns in Sardinia. The cohort includes 34,469 relative pairs. To extract genetic information, we implemented software for variance components heritability analysis, designed to handle large pedigrees, analyze multiple traits simultaneously, and model heterogeneity. Here, we report heritability analyses for 98 quantitative traits, in 1500 individuals, based on genotyping with an Affymetrix 500K SNP array platform, focusing on facets of personality and cardiovascular function. The association results presented are from Sardinia genome wide association analysis of body mass index. The sample size is 1410 (658 males and 752 females) and covariates are age, age square and sex.

Here, we report heritability analyses for 98 quantitative traits, in 1500 individuals, based on genotyping with an Affymetrix 500K SNP array platform, focusing on facets of personality and cardiovascular function. The association results presented are from Sardinia genome wide association analysis of hip (cm). The sample size is 1411 (659 males and 752 females) and covariates are age, age square and sex.

We recruited a cohort of 6,148 participants, aged 14-102 y, from four clustered towns in Sardinia. The cohort includes 34,469 relative pairs. To extract genetic information, we implemented software for variance components heritability analysis, designed to handle large pedigrees, analyze multiple traits simultaneously, and model heterogeneity. Here, we report heritability analyses for 98 quantitative traits, in 1500 individuals, based on genotyping with an Affymetrix 500K SNP array platform, focusing on facets of personality and cardiovascular function. The association results presented are from Sardinia genome wide association analysis of serum creatinine (mg/dl). The sample size is 1409 (657 males and 752 females) and covariates are age, age square and sex.

To extract genetic information, we implemented software for variance components heritability analysis, designed to handle large pedigrees, analyze multiple traits simultaneously, and model heterogeneity. Here, we report heritability analyses for 98 quantitative traits, in 1500 individuals, based on genotyping with an Affymetrix 500K SNP array platform, focusing on facets of personality and cardiovascular function. The association results presented are from Sardinia genome wide association analysis of trait from NEO Personality Inventory - Revised: warmth. The sample size is 1277 (583 males and 694 females) and covariates are age, age square and sex.

We recruited a cohort of 6,148 participants, aged 14-102 y, from four clustered towns in Sardinia. The cohort includes 34,469 relative pairs. To extract genetic information, we implemented software for variance components heritability analysis, designed to handle large pedigrees, analyze multiple traits simultaneously, and model heterogeneity. Here, we report heritability analyses for 98 quantitative traits, in 1500 individuals, based on genotyping with an Affymetrix 500K SNP array platform, focusing on facets of personality and cardiovascular function. The association results presented are from Sardinia genome wide association analysis of prostate-specific antigen (u/l). The sample size is 657 (657 males and 0 females) and covariates are age, age square and sex.

We recruited a cohort of 6,148 participants, aged 14-102 y, from four clustered towns in Sardinia. The cohort includes 34,469 relative pairs. To extract genetic information, we implemented software for variance components heritability analysis, designed to handle large pedigrees, analyze multiple traits simultaneously, and model heterogeneity. Here, we report heritability analyses for 98 quantitative traits, in 1500 individuals, based on genotyping with an Affymetrix 500K SNP array platform, focusing on facets of personality and cardiovascular function. The association results presented are from Sardinia genome wide association analysis of thyroid stimulating hormone (u/l). The sample size is 739 (3 males and 736 females) and covariates are age, age square and sex.

Here, we report heritability analyses for 98 quantitative traits, in 1500 individuals, based on genotyping with an Affymetrix 500K SNP array platform, focusing on facets of personality and cardiovascular function. The association results presented are from Sardinia genome wide association analysis of glycated hemoglobin(%). We recruited a cohort of 6,148 participants, aged 14-102 y, from four clustered towns in Sardinia. The cohort includes 34,469 relative pairs. To extract genetic information, we implemented software for variance components heritability analysis, designed to handle large pedigrees, analyze multiple traits simultaneously, and model heterogeneity. Here, we report heritability analyses for 98 quantitative traits, in 1500 individuals, based on genotyping with an Affymetrix 500K SNP array platform, focusing on facets of personality and cardiovascular function. The association results presented are from Sardinia genome wide association analysis of serum glucose level (mg/dl). The sample size is 1412 (659 males and 753 females) and covariates are age, age square and sex.

To extract genetic information, we implemented software for variance components heritability analysis, designed to handle large pedigrees, analyze multiple traits simultaneously, and model heterogeneity. Here, we report heritability analyses for 98 quantitative traits, in 1500 individuals, based on genotyping with an Affymetrix 500K SNP array platform, focusing on facets of personality and cardiovascular function. The association results presented are from Sardinia genome wide association analysis of serum insulin level (u/ml). The sample size is 1369 (643 males and 726 females) and covariates are age, age square and sex.
